intro: Cephaloschoenus globosus var. armeria, commonly known as the New Zealand flax, is a member of the Poaceae family. It is characterized by its tall, slender stems and narrow, grass-like leaves. The plant produces small, spike-like inflorescences that bear tiny, greenish flowers. It is native to New Zealand and thrives in moist, temperate climates. This variety is often used in traditional Māori weaving due to its strong, fibrous leaves.
